properties.name: School District of Philadelphia
properties.description: Born in the midst of the COVID 19 pandemic, this module explores isolation and the idea that through technology, each one of us shared a glimpse into what would otherwise have been a private space. Serving over 200,000 students in 339 schools, speaking 107 languages, the School District of Philadelphia is the 8th largest in the nation, with annual budget of 3 billion dollars. Rehearsing Philadelphia makes this location of power accessible through a solo performance by Frank Machos created by Fred Schmidt-Arenales.

properties.name: Philadelphia Police Department Headquarters
properties.description: Born in the midst of the COVID 19 pandemic, this module explores isolation and the idea that through technology, each one of us shared a glimpse into what would otherwise have been a private space. The fourth largest police force in the nation, the Philadelphia Police Department employs more than 6,300 sworn members and 800 civilian personnel. Rehearsing Philadelphia makes this location of power accessible through a solo performance by Officer Stephanie Velasquez created by Ei Arakawa.

properties.name: Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania
properties.description: Born in the midst of the COVID 19 pandemic, this module explores isolation and the idea that through technology, each one of us shared a glimpse into what would otherwise have been a private space. The hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, the number one ranked hospital in the United States, is also the nation’s first hospital (1751) and medical school (1765). Rehearsing Philadelphia makes this location of power accessible through a solo performance by Dr. Andrea Apter created by Germaine Ingram.

properties.name: City Hall
properties.description: Born in the midst of the COVID 19 pandemic, this module explores isolation and the idea that through technology, each one of us shared a glimpse into what would otherwise have been a private space. With over 700 rooms, Philadelphia’s City Hall is the largest municipal building in the United States and one of the largest in the world, housing all three branches of government, the city’s executive branch (Mayor’s Office), its legislature (Philadelphia City Council), and a substantial portion of the judicial activity in the city. Rehearsing Philadelphia makes this location of power accessible through a solo performance by Reverend Naomi Washington-Leapheart created by Yolanda Wisher.

properties.name: Community Legal Services
properties.description: Born in the midst of the COVID 19 pandemic, this module explores isolation and the idea that through technology, each one of us shared a glimpse into what would otherwise have been a private space. Founded by the Philadelphia Bar Association in 1966, CLS has provided free legal assistance to more than one million low-income Philadelphians facing the threat of losing their homes, incomes, health care and even families. Rehearsing Philadelphia makes this location of power accessible through a solo performance by Jonathan Stein created by CA Conrad.

properties.name: Benjamin Franklin Parkway
properties.description: 'Duet: Parkway' takes place along the Parkway from City Hall to the Philadelphia Museum of Art from 11am-2pm on Saturday, April 9, 2022.  Explore all the different locations along this route.

properties.name: City Hall, the Building
properties.description: City Hall took 30 years to build and cost nearly $25 million. The largest masonry building in the world, it was also the first secular building to hold the tallest habitable building distinction, surpassing religious buildings like cathedrals and pyramids. City Hall currently houses Philadelphia's municipal government.

properties.name: William Penn, Memorialized
properties.description: A 37-foot-tall bronze statue of William Penn designed by Alexander Milne Calder stands on top of City Hall, even though Penn was a Quaker and didn't believe in naming buildings (or squares) after people. Calder wanted the statue to face south, so the sun would hit his profile, but it actually faces northeast toward Sakimauchheen Ing or Penn Treaty Park, memorialized as the place where Tamanend and Penn made a treaty in 1682.  Edmond Bacon saw City Hall as a critical element to the city’s historical continuity, and for years challenged private developers' proposals for taller buildings with an unspoken gentleman’s agreement stating nothing should be built taller than the top of Penn's hat.

properties.name: Occupy
properties.description: Occupy Philadelphia protesters encamped at Dilworth Plaza outside City Hall protesting economic inequality for eight weeks in 2011. In the early morning hours of November 30th, Philadelphia police evacuated the Occupy encampment, making way for the $55 million dollar renovation, which reopened as Dilworth Park in 2014. Center City District, a private company, now has a thirty year lease of this historically public space.

properties.name: Octavius Catto Memorial
properties.description: Octavius Catto advocated for the desegregation of Philadelphia's street cars, taught at the Institute for Colored Youth, was a major figure at the Banneker Institute, and founded a Black baseball team, the Pythian Baseball Club. He was murdered on Election Day 1871 by a member of an armed group of white voters intent on suppressing black votes. This was the first public monument honoring a specific Black person in Philadelphia, and the first to be installed since the neighboring statue of John Wanamaker was raised in 1932.

properties.name: William McKinley
properties.description: McKinley served as President of the United States from 1897 until his assassination in 1901. In September of 1901, the same year City Hall was completed, McKinley was killed by a steelworker and self-identified anarchist Leon Czolgosz, who was put to death by electric chair. McKinley gave a presidential speech dedicating the Washington Monument when it was first placed in Fairmount Park in 1897.

properties.name: Wanamaker
properties.description: Born in what is now known as the Grays Ferry section of Philadelphia, John Wanamaker opened the “Grand Depot” at 13th and Market (where Macy's is now) in 1876. It eventually became Wanamaker's, the largest retail store in the world. Four hundred thousand Philadelphians contributed $35,000 to a fund to raise this statue of him, which reads 'Citizen.'  Not mentioned here are 'the expedition(s) of citizenship' sponsored by his son, Rodman Wanamaker and the Pennsylvania Railroad. These were trips in 1908 and 1909 to visit Native American tribes as part of an increasing white American interest in Native culture and their assimilation into white American society.

properties.name: Anna Jarvis
properties.description: Following her mother’s 1905 death, Anna Jarvis conceived of Mother’s Day as a way to honor the sacrifices mothers made for their children. Other attempts had been made at organizing days honoring moms, including some made by Anna's own mother, but it took President Woodrow Wilson signing a resolution recognizing Mother’s Day in 1914 for it to become nationally celebrated. Eventually, Jarvis became so incensed by the commercialization and politicization of Mother’s Day that in 1933 she wrote to President Franklin Roosevelt beseeching him to remove the holiday from the nation’s official calendar. She died alone in an asylum and is buried in West Laurel Hill Cemetery.

properties.name: Fallen Firemen
properties.description: A storage tank explosion and ensuing release of toxic fumes on October 28, 1954 at the Charles Berg Laboratories killed ten fire fighters, honored here. The tank contained ethylene and propylene-dichloride and ortho-dichlorobenzene which are mixed to prepare a cleaning fluid for rugs and other fabrics; any one of these compounds is poisonous, if inhaled in sufficient quantity. The memorial is placed on the North East corner of City Hall, pointing to 5th and Berks, where the explosion occurred.

properties.name: John Christian Bullitt
properties.description: Born in Kentucky, John Christian Bullitt was a primary author of the 'Bullitt Bill,' which became the Philadelphia City Charter in 1887 and concentrated the power of municipal rule in the hands of the Mayor. Bullitt was a prominent lawyer and helped found Philadelphia's Central Democratic Club, established during the Civil War to defend the proposition that 'in the State of Pennsylvania, all power is inherent in the White People.' His father, a planter, enslaved of more than 100 Black people. This bronze was commissioned by the citizens of Philadelphia in 1902.

properties.name: Gloria Casarez
properties.description: Latina lesbian civil rights leader, Gloria Casarez helped found the Philly Dyke March and the homeless advocacy group Empty the Shelters. She worked as executive director at GALAEI before being appointed Philadelphia’s first director of the Office of LGBT Affairs. She shepherded a comprehensive LGBTQ rights bill through City Council in 2013, which provides tax credits for companies that offered domestic partner and trans health care benefits.

properties.name: Mother Jones
properties.description: After Mary G. Harris Jones' husband and four children all died of yellow fever in 1867, and the Great Chicago Fire of 1871 destroyed her dress shop, she became an organizer for the Knights of Labor and the United Mine Workers union. In 1902, she was called 'the most dangerous woman in America' for her success in organizing mine workers and their families against the mine owners. In 1903, to protest the lax enforcement of the child labor laws in the Pennsylvania mines and silk mills, she organized a children's march from Kensington, Philadelphia to the home of President Theodore Roosevelt in Oyster Bay, New York.

properties.name: General George McClellan
properties.description: George McClellan, a Philadelphia native, ran for president against Lincoln in 1864, was an American soldier, Civil War Union general, civil engineer, railroad executive, and served as the 24th Governor of New Jersey. Though committed to the preservation of the Union, he defended the property rights of slaveholders. McClellan Street in South Philadelphia is named after him as well as the McClellan saddle.

properties.name: Major General John F. Reynolds
properties.description: Born in Lancaster, Major General John F. Reynolds spent his adulthood in the military—his assignments included the Mexican-American War, the so-called Rogue River Wars of 1856, and the Utah War with the mormons in 1857. As one of the Union's leading general officers, Reynolds was killed during the first day of fighting at the Battle of Gettysburg on July 1, 1863. A musket ball struck him in the back of the neck, killing him instantly.

properties.name: Rizzo Statue Removed
properties.description: Frank Rizzo served Philadelphia as a policeman, Police Commissioner, and two-term mayor. Unveiled in 1999, and created by sculptor and PAFA alumnus Zenos Frudakis, the statue was donated to the city and paid for by private contributions from his family, friends, and supporters. Before the statue's removal in 2020, it had been contested multiple times—in 2013, after the acquittal of George Zimmerman in the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin, when adorned with a sign reading 'this system is still racist' ; in 2016, when covered with a white hood that mimicked those worn by the Ku Klux Klan; in 2017, when tagged with the words 'Black Power'; in 2019, when spray-painted with the word 'fascist'; and in 2020, when defaced with red paint during the George Floyd protests.

properties.name: Love Gap
properties.description: Edmund Bacon and Vincent Kling didn't intend to build one of the greatest skate spots in the world, but skate culture found LOVE and made it a mecca. Legends, local and otherwise, traversed the beloved LOVE Gap for much of the 90s. In 2000, City Council passed a bill banning skateboarding from the park. In 2002, the park was closed for a renovation intended to make it un-skateable. DC Shoes offered to pay $1 million for 10 years of upkeep of the park if skateboarding was allowed; the city turned the company down. On February 10th, 2016, Mayor Kenney lifted the ban for five days to honor the park's skate history one last time before its permanent close.

properties.name: LOVE Park
properties.description: Closed in 2016 for a two-year reconstruction aimed at stopping leaks into the underground concourse and parking lot below, the redesign of LOVE park flattened a multilevel public square into a relatively featureless plateau.  While the park is more accessible now, critics have cited concerns about its hostile design, specifically the seating and lack of shade, which many believe are aimed at the unhoused. The southeast corner is officially named the Bank of America plaza and garden in recognition of a $250,000 donation from the financial institution.

properties.name: Monument to Six Million Jewish Martyrs
properties.description: In 1964, the Monument to Six Million Jewish Martyrs was presented to the city by a group of Holocaust survivors who worked with the Association of Jewish New Americans and the Federation of Jewish Agencies of Greater Philadelphia to make the public art piece happen. It now sits in the context of the newly developed Horwitz-Wasserman Holocaust Plaza, a nine million dollar project which opened in 2018 to educate visitors about the genocide, and those who suffered it, enacted by Nazi Germany between 1941 and 1945.  The Philadelphia Holocaust Remembrance Foundation has been working on the project since 2006.

properties.name: Three Way Piece Number 1: Points
properties.description: Three Way Piece Number 1: Points, purchased by the Fairmount Park Art Association in 1967 and located at the foot of the Parkway in 1990. The design was, in part, inspired by a small piece of flint. Henry Moore (1898-1986), British, is renowned for his semi-abstract monumental bronzes, which can be seen all over the world.

properties.name: Three Discs, One Lacking
properties.description: Alexander Calder, son of Alexander Sterling Calder, who sculpted the Swann Fountain up at Logan Circle, and grandson of Alexander Milne Calder, whose statues adorn City Hall, was born in 1898 in Lawnton, PA. He started out as a mechanical engineer because, allegedly, his parents didn't want him to become an artist. Edmund Bacon, Director of Philadelphia’s City Planning Commission, purchased this iron alloy painted sculpture for the City in 1968. If you get down on all fours and look through the circle of steel that Calder has removed, you'll notice that it references the work of his grandfather through its framing.

properties.name: Kopernick
properties.description: Copernicus dedicated his book, On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres, to the Pope, but the Catholic Church placed it on the Index of Prohibited Books—pending revision—in 1616. The Church ended the ban a few years later after editing the text to present Copernicus's views as wholly hypothetical. In 1633, 90 years after Copernicus's death, the Church convicted astronomer Galileo Galilei of 'strong suspicion of heresy' for espousing Copernicus's theory of heliocentrism. Positioned across from the Basilica Cathedral of Saints Peter and Paul, the memorial sculpture by Connecticut artist Dudley Talcott was commissioned and donated to the city by a committee of Polish Americans formed to honor Kopernik on the 500th anniversary of his birth.

properties.name: Kościuszko
properties.description: Polish-lithuanian military engineer and army officer, Tadeusz Kościuszko fought for the United States in the American Revolutionary War and led a national insurrection in his homeland against the Russian empire. After wounding, capture, imprisonment, and banishment from his native Poland, he recuperated at Mrs. Ann Relf's boarding house on Third and Pine Streets in Philadelphia. Before leaving the US for the final time, he made a will in 1798 stipulating that the proceeds of his American estate be spent on freeing and educating enslaved African-Americans, including those owned by his friend Thomas Jefferson, whom he named as the will's executor. Thomas Jefferson failed to execute the will, and the case of the Kościuszko's American estate reached the U.S. Supreme Court three times. None of the resources that Kościuszko had earmarked for the manumission and education of African-Americans were ever used for that purpose.

properties.name: AMOR
properties.description: On the occasion of Pope Francis’ visit to the U.S. in 2015, the Association for Public Art and the Philadelphia Museum of Art brought Robert Indiana’s AMOR to Philadelphia. Indiana created the Spanish/Latin version of the sculpture, AMOR, in 1998. AMOR means “love” in both Pope Francis’ native Spanish and the Church’s traditional Latin.

properties.name: Thomas Fitzsimons
properties.description: An Irish immigrant, Thomas Fitzsimons founded a major trading company that provided supplies and funds to American forces during the Revolutionary War. A signer of the U.S. Constitution (one of three Catholic signers), he served three terms in Congress. When he sat as a member of the General Assembly of Pennsylvania, he was opposed to universal suffrage and wanted to keep the vote to landholding white men. The Society of the Friends of St. Patrick erected this bronze memorial.

properties.name: Gallows at Northwest Square
properties.description: Before conceived of as a square or park, hardwood forest covered this area, part of the greater landscape of Lenapehoking. It was named Northwest square by William Penn, and in early colonial days, like many of Philadelphia's squares, was used as a potter's field and pasture. This particular square was also the site of Philadelphia's public executions when hanging was the common method. Pennsylvania abolished public executions in 1834. Since then, execution has moved from the electric chair and lethal gas to lethal injections administered with chemicals and needles.

properties.name: Logan Square, Namesake
properties.description: James Logan, after whom this square was named in 1825, served a myriad of roles within colonial Pennsylvania including Philadelphia mayor, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, and William Penn's colonial secretary. In the latter role, he was part of orchestrating a land grab called The Walking Purchase of 1737, where he and others, including William Penn's sons, swindled the Lenape out of approximately one million acres of land north of Tohickon creek.

properties.name: Swann Memorial Fountain
properties.description: In 1924, the 124-foot Swann Memorial Fountain was unveiled in the center of Logan Circle. Architect Wilson Eyre, Jr. designed the fountain and collaborated with sculptor Alexander Stirling Calder, who adapted the Roman tradition of “river god” sculpture and used large Native American figures to symbolize the area’s major local waterways: the Delaware River, the Schuylkill River, and Wissahickon Creek. The sculpture is dedicated to the memory of Dr. Wilson Cary Swann, founder of the Philadelphia Fountain Society, an organization committed to making public drinking water more widely available for humans and horses.

properties.name: Square Made Circle
properties.description: Logan Square lost its edge and became a circle in 1917 during the construction of the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. Jacques Gréber, a French landscape architect, designed the circle to mimic the Place de la Concorde in Paris. In 1999, the Center City District dared to propose re-squaring Logan Circle; the idea was quickly abandoned, but has been raised numerous times since.

properties.name: Great Sanitary Fair
properties.description: In 1864 the square was the site of the Great Sanitary Fair, a fundraising event in support of the United States Sanitary Commission to help raise money, support, and buy medicine for the Union troops during the American Civil War. President Abraham Lincoln visited the fair and donated forty-eight signed copies of the Emancipation Proclamation, which sold for $10 each. The Great Central Fair successfully combined the feeling of traditional ladies’ “fancy” and “floral fairs” and the more masculine industrial exhibitions that had become popular in the nineteenth century.

properties.name: Pennypacker
properties.description: Galusha Pennypacker, a native of Chester County and born to a family with a long history of military service, became the youngest general to serve in the Civil War.  After fighting for the Union Army, during which he was wounded seven times, he served in the south, running the Department of Mississippi. While there, he did not actively hold the KKK to account for lynchings in Yalobusha County.  If you're confused about the style of his dress, you're in good company; in keeping with the Beaux-Arts tradition, the monument portrays the youthful general in classical costume—garb he probably did not wear at his house on south 10th St in Philadelphia during retirement.

properties.name: Shakespeare Memorial
properties.description: Erected in 1926, The Shakespeare Memorial depicts characters Hamlet and Touchstone. The original site for the memorial in front of the Free Library was carefully selected by representatives from both the Fairmount Park Art Association and the Shakespeare Memorial Committee, with additional input from architects Gilbert McIlvaine, Paul Cret, and Jacques Gréber. Cast in 1926 by the Roman Bronze Works, the sculpture was dedicated on Shakespeare’s birthday in 1929. Because of expressway construction, the memorial was moved in 1953 to its present location.

properties.name: Caliban's Hands
properties.description: According to the artist, Christopher Myers, Caliban’s Hands, is symbolic of the indigenous lands and cultures occupied and suppressed by European colonial societies, and speaks to the dynamics of privilege, oppression, and forced servitude.  As a part of Kindred Arts Monumental Tour in 2021, the statue's installation was temporary, but strategically placed next to the Shakespeare Memorial.

properties.name: All Wars Memorial to Colored Soldiers and Sailors
properties.description: The Honorable Samuel Beecher Hart, a Pennsylvania legislator and captain of the Gray Invincibles, the last “colored” unit in the Pennsylvania Militia, proposed a memorial to African American military men from Pennsylvania who served the United States in wartime. In 1927, when the military was still segregated, funds were appropriated to construct the memorial, but its placement was intensely debated between the the Colored Soldiers Statue Commission, the Art Jury, the Fairmount Park Commission, and, to some degree, the public. After nearly seven years of deliberation, including racial aggressions, protests, and political football, the memorial finally landed in a hidden corner behind Memorial Hall in Fairmount Park, where few residents and tourists encountered it. The Committee to Restore and Relocate The All Wars Memorial to Colored Soldiers and Sailors successfully advocated for its relocation here on the Parkway in 1994.

properties.name: Francisco De Miranda
properties.description: Francisco De MIranda, born into the upper class of Caracas in present-day Venezuela, participated in three major historical and political movements of his time: the American Revolutionary War, the French Revolution and the Spanish American Wars of Independence. When he published the Peruvian Juan Pablo Viscardo’s Carta dirigida a los Españoles Americanos (1799), he honored Philadelphia as the place of publication, even though he published the work in London. In 1812, as the First Venezuelan Republic was crumbling, Miranda broke from his fellow revolutionaries, including Simon Bolivar, and signed an armistice with royalist forces—a betrayal that ultimately landed him in Spanish prison, where he remained until his death in 1816.

properties.name: Civil War Soldiers and Sailors Memorial
properties.description: Originally installed in 1921 as gates to the 'Parkway Gardens,' the two pylons were moved 150 feet towards the Art Museum in 1955, to allow for the building of the Vine Street Expressway. The memorial was designed as a kind of Arc de Triomphe, but for the United States, celebrating the preservation of the Union ('One Nation, One Constitution, One Destiny.'). The monument, which mentions slavery once, was first proposed to Philadelphia's City Council in 1918, when WWI was still ongoing, and the generation that had fought the Civil War was passing away.

properties.name: The Barnes
properties.description: The original Barnes was completed by 1925 in Merion, PA, with the design and construction led by French architect Paul Philippe Cret. After much debate and controversy, the Barnes Foundation moved in 2012 to its current home, designed by architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, in downtown Philadelphia. The facility houses one of the most comprehensive 9,000-piece collections of post-impressionist, impressionist, and early modern paintings with an estimated value of $20-$30 billion. Barnes’s successful career in the pharmaceutical industry laid the groundwork for his foundation. He built a fortune manufacturing Argyrol, a widely used antiseptic that he developed with German chemist Hermann Hille.

properties.name: 1967 Student Walkout
properties.description: On November 17, 1967, more than 3,000 Philadelphia public school students walked out of their classrooms to protest racism and inequity within the school system. Many converged outside the old Board of Education building at 21st and Winter streets, not far from here. Inside, two dozen students met with then-Superintendent Mark Shedd and then-Board Chairman Richardson Dilworth to negotiate a list of 25 demands, including the removal of police from school settings, the integration of African American studies into the curriculum, and the freedom for Black students to wear African dashikis and kufis and natural hair in school. Walter Palmer described the mood ouside as one of  'hope, energy, and possibility,' which quicklu shifted when Police Commissioner Rizzo arrived with busloads of about 300 officers with helmets and nightsticks. Teenage protesters were beaten; 57 protesters—39 teenagers and 18 adults—were arrested. In the immediate aftermath, Philadelphia school administrators began work to incorporate African American history into the curriculum. It would not be until 2005 that the district would require all students to take a course in the subject, becoming the first public school system in the U.S. to do so. In March of 2020, five Juniors at Masterman High School won approval by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission to erect a marker to honor and preserve the legacy of the 3,000 students who participated in the 1967 walkouts. They are now awaiting permission from the PMC Property group which owns the former Board of Education building, now used for parkway apartments.

properties.name: The Thinker
properties.description: Rodin made at least ten castings of The Thinker in his lifetime. Philadelphia's version is installed in front of a façade that replicates the arrangement at Rodin’s tomb. The first version was smaller and intended to be a part of The Gates of Hell tableaux, which Rodin made, in part, to debunk circulating rumors of surmoulage – to take a cast from a living model. It was only later, after the installation plans for The Gates of Hell fell through, that Rodin reworked many of the figures, including The Thinker, which he enlarged in bronze in the early 1900s.

properties.name: Rodin Museum
properties.description: The Rodin Museum, designed by Cret and Gréber, was a gift from movie-theatre magnate Jules Mastbaum to the city of Philadelphia.  Jules E. Mastbaum was a product of Philadelphia public schools and a graduate of the Wharton School of Business. Starting in 1905 by showing one-reel films in a small storefront at Eighth and Market Streets, brothers Jules and Stanley would eventually build The Stanley Company of America, the largest theater chain in the United States, owning and operating motion picture theaters throughout Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Delaware.

properties.name: Camp JDT, Summer 2020
properties.description: In the midst of Black Lives Matter protests in the summer of 2020, unhoused Philadelphians organized encampments here that provided community and basic services, including a kitchen, a medical tent and a library. The protesters captured local and national attention and resisted the constant threat of eviction. A black banner hung above their tents proclaiming HOUSING NOW! In October 2020, after weeks of negotiations between representatives of the encampment, the city and the PHA, the parties struck a legally binding agreement in which fifty vacant homes, half from PHA and half from the city, would be transferred to the encampment residents through a to-be-established community land trust.

properties.name: Camp JDT, Summer 2020
properties.description: In the midst of Black Lives Matter protests in the summer of 2020, unhoused Philadelphians organized encampments here that provided community and basic services, including a kitchen, a medical tent and a library. The protesters captured local and national attention and resisted the constant threat of eviction. A black banner hung above their tents proclaiming HOUSING NOW! In October 2020, after weeks of negotiations between representatives of the encampment, the city and the PHA, the parties struck a legally binding agreement in which fifty vacant homes, half from PHA and half from the city, would be transferred to the encampment residents through a to-be-established community land trust.

properties.name: All Power to All People
properties.description: A version of Hank Willis Thomas’ All Power to All People, sat across from City Hall on Thomas Paine Plaza in Fall 2017, serving as a public art intervention, and a larger version stood here in 2021 as part of Kindred Arts' Monumental Tour. 'Thomas has deep family connections to Philadelphia, including his maternal grandmother, Ruth, who was a beautician in North Philadelphia; his mother, Deborah, a celebrated archivist and professor of African American photography; and his father, Hank, a jazz musician and former Black Panther.' The artwork’s name derives from a rallying call popularized in speeches by Black Panther Party activist Fred Hampton, who was murdered in a raid by local and federal authorities in Chicago in 1969.

properties.name: Washington Monument
properties.description: The monument consists of three zones or levels—Washington, isolated as hero, sits at the top; female figures are used allegorically to depict America as Liberty and 'Call to Arms';  flora, fauna, and humans are used to populate the lower level. The Society of the Cincinnati of Pennsylvania, founded at the City Tavern in 1783 to commemorate those who had fought together during the War of Independence, commissioned Rudolf Siemering of Berlin to design the monument. Unveiled in May 1897 at the Green Street entrance to Fairmount Park, the monument was installed to its current location in front of the PMA in 1928. The event was celebrated nationally, with William McKinley presiding over the dedication ceremony.

properties.name: Oval Named After Eakins
properties.description: A traffic circle that connects the core of the city with Fairmount Park, Kelly Drive, and Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive. Part of urban planner Jacques Gréber's design for the Benjamin Franklin Parkway, the oval was named after Thomas Eakins. Eakins was a Philadelphian, fine arts educator, and a celebrated realist painter with a documented history of sexual misconduct and abuse. He grew up with a mother who lived with bipolar disorder. Artist Mary Enoch Elizabeth Baxter currently has a petition out to PAFA, who owns many of Eakin's images, calling for the removal of Eakin's name from all landmarks, amongst other demands to support the well-being of Black women.

properties.name: Eli Kirk Price II Fountain
properties.description: Prominent American Philadelphia lawyer, commissioner of Fairmount Park during the planning and development of the Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Eli Kirk Price II was instrumental in obtaining funding for the new Philadelphia Museum of Art building and was President of the museum from 1926–1933. He received his Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Laws degrees from the University of Pennsylvania respectively, and was admitted to the Pennsylvania bar in 1883.Price was responsible for the purchase and installation of the sculpture of Billy the goat in Rittenhouse Square. He died in 1933 of a heart attack and is buried in Woodlands Cemetery, Philadelphia.

properties.name: John Ericsson Fountain
properties.description: A Swedish-American inventor and engineer known for revolutionizing naval warfare. He's remembered for his design of the first ironclad warship, the USS Monitor, which played an important role in the blockade of the Confederacy by the Union Navy in the American Civil War. Ericsson also explored solar energy;  he constructed a solar observatory on the roof of his home at 36 Beach Street in Manhattan and built working sun engines.

properties.name: Edifice
properties.description: Construction of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, which used dolomite quarried in Minnesota, began in 1919, but wasn't completed until 1928.  Enlisting the creativity of Frank Gehry, the Philadelphia Museum of Art has now completed a 233 million dollar renovation and reorganisation of the lower interior spaces. The museum houses more than 240,000 objects.

properties.name: Julian Abele
properties.description: Between 1906, when he joined the all-white Philadelphia firm of Horace Trumbauer, and his death in 1950, Julian Abele designed, in part or whole, some 250 buildings, including Harvard’s Widener Memorial Library, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Free Library of Philadelphia, and a host of Gilded Age mansions in Newport and New York City. He attended the Institute for Colored Youth and went on to be the first Black graduate of the University of Pennsylvania architecture department's in 1902. Julian Abele Park, located at 22nd Street between Montrose and Carpenter Streets in Philadelphia, PA, bears his name.

properties.name: Million Woman March
properties.description: A rally organized on October 25, 1997 by Phile Chionesu and Asia Coney, two Philadelphia grassroots activists, to celebrate family unity, foster social and economic empowerment throughout Black communities, and to honor what it means to be a woman of African descent in America. Using a network of women’s organizations and relying on fliers, leaflets, Black-run media, the Internet and “word-of-mouth” to spread the word, the Million Woman March drew a crowd of thousands, estimated anywhere beteen 500,000 and 2.1 million. Unlike the Million Man March two years earlier, the Million Woman March did not rely on big names or the celebrities of the civil rights movement to fuel attendance. Nonetheless several influential Black women attended and spoke including Winnie Madikizela-Mandela and California Congresswoman Maxine Waters.

properties.name: 'Rocky' Steps
properties.description: 72 to be precise. Made of stone and now known by many as the 'Rocky Steps' as a result of a scene from the film Rocky, where Sylvester Stallone climbs them during a training montage. After filming was complete, a debate arose between the Art Museum and Philadelphia Art Commission over whether the Rocky statue located just below was 'art' or a 'movie prop.' Nonetheless, the steps, and the climb up them, are still a widely-referenced cultural icon. They also serve as a stage for events, rallies, protests. One recent example: hundreds of demonstrators staged a die-in on the steps on July 5th, 2020 to protest ongoing police brutality.

properties.name: Heat Waves
properties.description: Fountains around the Philadelphia Museum of Art, including ones that used to cascade along the side of the 72 steps, were used by the public to cool down during summer months. The average summer temperature in Philadelphia has risen 3 degrees since 1970, the decade when Dick Swanson captured Philadelphians cooling off in the series Documerica. Rising heat especially affects economically stressed neighborhoods populated mostly by Black and Latino residents, like Hunting Park, where there are more heat-absorbing hard surfaces and fewer tree-lined streets to offer residents shade. Check out your neighborhoods heat vulnerability index here.

properties.name: Old City
properties.description: 'Duet: Old City' takes place around Independence Historic Park from 11am-2pm on Saturday, April 2, 2022.  Explore all the different locations along this route.

properties.name: Congo or Southeast Square
properties.description: A Potter's field for those who could not afford a burial plot for the bodies of their loved ones, a gathering place for the African American community to celebrate and protect the traditions of their homelands, a resting place for those taken by the Yellow Fever, ravaged by war, or imprisoned at the nearby Walnut St Jail—many unnamed lay here.

properties.name: Walnut St Jail Turned Prison
properties.description: The Walnut St Jail became a state prison in 1790. It enacted experimental reforms that led to the development of the Pennsylvania System, which would include labor, solitary confinement, and the separation and classification of the imprisoned, much of which still stands in some form in the current penal system today. The prison closed and was razed in 1835 and prisoners were relocated to Moyamensing Prison at 11th and East Passyunk.

properties.name: Ladies Home Journal
properties.description: Louisa Knapp Curtis was an American columnist and first editor of the Ladies' Home Journal from 1883 to 1889. The journal served as an instructional guide for the modern housewife, offering gardening tips, parenting advice, table settings, and the latest fashion. In 1890 she handed the job over to Edward Bok, a Dutch immigrant.  Bok was against letting women vote, but converted his “At Home with the Editor” question and answer segment to  'The Open Congress,' where he endorsed and disseminated national symbols supporting the Americanization of women and the greater populace. He married Louisa's daughter, Mary Louisa Curtis, who founded the Curtis Institute of Music and the Curtis Center.

properties.name: Ricketts' Art Pantheon and Amphitheatre
properties.description: Ricketts' Art Pantheon and Amphitheater stood here, seating about 1,300 audience members. John Ricketts came from England, where exhibitions of trick horse riding began in the 1760s. The centrifugal force needed to keep a standing rider on the back of a cantering horse determined the dimensions of the circus ring. The growth of the circus was coterminous with both the Enlightenment and the spread of European empire. Riders on horseback raced around the circus ring, sometimes pantomiming patriotic scenes from cavalry battles.This particular building burned down in a fire Dec. 17, 1799, but circus would continue to normalize colonial violence as spectacle through the 1800s.

properties.name: Liberty Bell
properties.description: In 1751, the Pennsylvania Assembly ordered a bell to commemorate the 50-year anniversary of William Penn's 1701 Charter of Privileges. Abolitionists later adopted it as as a symbol of freedom, promised but not achieved. William Lloyd Garrison's publication The Liberator reprinted a Boston abolitionist pamphlet containing a poem entitled The Liberty Bell in 1839. Since then it has become a widely recognized, referenced, and replicated symbol for social movements, protests, political meetings, and celebrations across the globe.

properties.name: The President's House
properties.description: The President's House: Freedom and Slavery in the Making of a New Nation opened on December 15, 2010 after African American groups such as Avenging the Ancestors Coalition and Generations Unlimited, local historians and journalists advocated for the National Park Service to acknowledge the history of slavery on the doorstep of the Liberty Bell. Two presidents, George Washington and John Adams, lived here when Philadelphia was the capital between 1790-1800. Nine people of African descent—Oney Judge, Moll, Austin, Hercules, Richmond, Giles, Paris, Christopher Sheels, and Joe (Richardson), whom the Washingtons enslaved, also lived here.

properties.name: Avenging the Ancestors Coalition
properties.description: Avenging The Ancestors Coalition (ATAC) is a broad-based organization of African American historians, attorneys, concerned citizens, elected officials, religious leaders, media personalities, community activists, and registered voters. ATAC was founded in 2002 to compel the National Park Service (NPS) and Independence National Historical Park (INHP) to finally agree to the creation of a prominent Slavery Memorial to conspicuously permeate the President’s House project.

properties.name: Visitors Center
properties.description: You might feel cut off from the park on 6th St starting at this corner with the brick wall facing you from The Independence Visitors Center, which opened in 2001 after the National Historic Park announced a redesign in 1997 with landscape architecture firm Olin Partnership. The NHS vetoed a window on Market Street for the center's bookstore because it felt the sight of commerce would demean the mall's dignity. Instead, the front of the building is camouflaged with Alison Sky's Indelible, an artwork that contains text about the condemnation of slavery edited out of the original draft of the Declaration of Independence by Congress in 1774.

properties.name: Fugitive Slave Law of 1850
properties.description: In front of the William J. Green, Jr. Federal Building, part of the larger Federal complex here including James A. Byrne United States Courthouse, we remember The Fugitive Slave Act of 1850, which was part of the Compromise of 1850, and many believed an embodiment of incursion of federal power into state sovereignty. The act required that the enslaved be returned to their owners, even if they were in a free state.  It also denied enslaved people the right to a jury trial and to testify on their own behalf.  In order to ensure the statute was enforced, the 1850 law also placed control of individual cases in the hands of federal commissioners, who were paid more for returning a suspected runaway than for freeing them.

properties.name: National Constitution Center
properties.description: The National Constitution Center opened on July 4, 2003 as a result of the Constitution Heritage Act, approved and signed by President Ronald Reagan in 1988. The act read, 'The Center shall disseminate information about the United States Constitution on a non-partisan basis in order to increase the awareness and understanding of the Constitution among the American people.' It was here, during the presidential race in 2008, that Senator Barack Obama delivered 'A More Perfect Union' in which he directly addressed racial division embedded nationally and personally, and also quelled a controversy that had begun to emerge around comments made by Jeremiah Wright, his pastor at the time, accusing the United States of terrorism, locally and abroad.

properties.name: First Earth Day
properties.description: On April 21st, 1970, the eve of Earth Day, Mexican-American/Native American rock band Redbone, in addition to the entire cast of the hit Broadway musical “Hair,” performed for an audience of about 20,000. A group of University of Pennsylvania Landscape Architecture and Regional Planning students decided in early 1970 to organize an entire Earth Week of activities, which attracted major local and national news coverage. Speakers included Ralph Nader, Alan Watts, Allen Ginsberg, and U.S. Senate Minority Leader, Hugh Scott.

properties.name: Philadelphia Female Anti-Slavery Society
properties.description: Created in 1833 when women could not join the newly ­formed American Anti­-Slavery Society, the interracial Philadelphia Female Anti-Slavery Society was headquartered here. Members petitioned for abolition and boycotted goods manufactured by the enslaved. From 1836 to 1854 the PFASS donated $13,845 (approximately $400,000 today) to the Pennsylvania Abolition Society, and supported the Underground Railroad through its contributions to the Philadelphia Vigilant Committee, organized in 1837 by Robert Purvis to aid those escaping from slavery in southeastern Pennsylvania. The Society organized its final fair, to support the movement for Black suffrage, in 1869, then disbanded in 1870 after ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment.

properties.name: Christ Church Burial Ground
properties.description: Initially open to the street until about 1740, this burial ground, owned by Christ Church, was fenced in to contain grazing animals. In 1722, the wooden fence was replaced with a seven-foot brick wall, near which Benjamin Franklin was interred in 1790. After prominent Bostonians criticized the city's maintenance of the grave and claimed Franklin as their own by erecting a statue of him there in 1856, multiple stakeholders vested in the Franklin name in Philadelphia—many from the Franklin Institute—began to work towards opening the wall to allow onlookers access to the grave. The effort was carefully staged to look as though it was brought on by the will of the public. The metal railing was installed in 1858 by Wood & Perot, a manufacturer of decorative ironwork whose factory was near 12th and Spring Garden.

properties.name: Mikveh Israel
properties.description: Mikveh Israel, the oldest synagogue in Philadelphia, is an active community synagogue with services on the Sabbath, holy days, and special occasions, and offers adult education and cultural programming with a focus on the Spanish and Portuguese tradition and history. In 1740, Nathan Levy applied to Thomas Penn, Royal Proprietor of Pennsylvania, for a plot to bury his child in accordance with Jewish ritual. It became a Jewish communal cemetery, the first evidence of Jewish communal life in Philadelphia, and how Mikveh Israel dates its beginning. The current building was dedicated  September 12th, 1976, two months after the Nation’s July 4th Bicentennial.

properties.name: The National Museum of American Jewish History
properties.description: Founded in 1976, The National Museum of American Jewish History originally shared a building with Congregation Mikveh Israel, but moved down the street to this building, which opened its doors to the public in November of 2010. In March of 2020, the museum filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, seeking relief from debt incurred by construction, and emerged in September 2021. During the pandemic, It was unable to apply for federal Paycheck Protection Program loans for its employees after filing for bankruptcy and, as a result, furloughed almost two-thirds of its staff without pay.

properties.name: The Bourse
properties.description: The concept of The Bourse — meaning a “place of exchange” — was brought to Philadelphia in 1890 by George E. Bartol, who came from a sugar manufacturing family. In the late 1800s, Philadelphia had over a dozen sugar refineries—factories which required a great deal of storage space for freight wagons, hogsheads (large barrels), lumber and trash. George's father, Barnabas Henry Bartol, was the head of the Grocers’ Sugar House (refinery) at 7th Street and Passyunk Avenue, three or four blocks from the Bethel Burying Ground. On January 1, 1869, Bartol signed a lease (terminated four years later) to use Bethel Burying Ground for a storage yard for a rent of $200 a year. It was acknowledged by Bethel Church that the property was formerly a cemetery and that the human remains were to remain undisturbed.

properties.name: Signer's Garden
properties.description: Across the street stands a statue of George Clymer, celebrated as signer of both the Declaration of Independence and the United States Constitution. He also represented Pennsylvania in the House of Representatives during the First Congress, which passed the Naturalization Act of 1790, limiting the right of citizenship to 'free white persons.' African Americans were not guaranteed citizenship until 1868, when the Fourteenth Amendment was ratified in the wake of Reconstruction. Groups of Native Americans became citizens through individual treaties or intermarriage and finally, through the 1924 Indian Citizenship Act. Asian immigrants were ineligible to citizenship until the 1954 McCarran-Walter Act, which removed racial barriers to naturalization.

properties.name: The Guarantee Trust and Safe Deposit Company
properties.description: Demolished in 1957, the Guarantee Trust and Safe Deposit Company, established in 1872, provided safe storage for securities, currency, jewelry, silver plate, and other valuables. Safe depositories became more common during the Civil War when the threat to personal possessions in battleground states was very real, and they continued to grow in number and popularity in the years after the war. Frank Furness, the building's architect, was commissioned to create plans for almost a dozen financial and trust company buildings in Philadelphia. His idiosyncratic designs provided his clients with visually distinctive structures and also tended to generate a great deal of publicity.

properties.name: Banker's Row
properties.description: Chestnut St, between 2nd and 5th streets, served as Banker's Row, or the Wall Street of a fledgling United States. Bankers strove to occupy the biggest and most secure-looking building on the block. Chestnut street's influence on a national level waned after President Andrew Jackson, who also signed the Indian Removal Act of 1830, vetoed the rechartering of The Second Bank. Nonetheless, it continued to be Philadelphia’s chief banking and business zone for the rest of the 19th century.

properties.name: Jayne Building
properties.description: The Jayne Building, an eight-story, 113-foot marvel, was the headquarters of the booming patent medicine business of Dr. David Jayne.  Designed by Philadelphia-born Thomas Ustick Walter and built between 1849 and 1851, the Jayne Building caught fire on a cold night in March, 1872. While its tower was destroyed, and despite the  Philadelphia Inquirer's eulogy, “The loss of so noble a building is one that the whole city will feel,”  the building remained until it was demolished between 1957-58 to make way for the Independence National Historic Park.

properties.name: Coocaconoon Dubbed Dock Creek
properties.description: An inlet and outlet for Lenape canoes, settlers renamed Coocaconoon, a tributary that flowed inland, Dock Creek. The earliest elite Philadelphia settlers had their homes built here, followed by breweries and tanneries , whose refuse eventually polluted the creek enough that the newly local residents started calling the creek a 'nuisance.' Eventually, the city decided the nuisance ought to be plugged and buried it underground.

properties.name: Site of Exchange, Stock or Otherwise
properties.description: After the The Merchant's Coffee House (reconstructed in 1975 and renamed The City Tavern) across the street burned down in a fire in 1834, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange relocated here to this building, designed by William Strickland. Starting in the 1920s, the Merchants Exchange building became the centerpiece of the city's produce exchange, with market sheds attached to the marble walls and a rusty metal roof skirting its colonnade. The building now serves as the National Park's headquarters.

properties.name: Polish American Social Services, PASS
properties.description: Polish American Social Services (PASS) began in 1908 as a service to help new immigrants from Poland arriving through the Immigrant Port of Entry at Washington and Delaware Avenues in South Philadelphia. The agency, through its United Social Services Outreach Program, continues to help elderly and low-income citizens, especially those with language barriers, who frequently have difficulty understanding and accessing city, state and federal programs designed to improve or maintain their quality of life.

properties.name: Old St Joseph's Church
properties.description: The first Roman Catholic church in Philadelphia, Old St Joseph's, was founded in 1733. Nowhere else in the English colonies could Catholics enjoy public worship to the extent possible in 18th-century Philadelphia.  Anti-Catholic rioters attacked the church on at least two occasions in 1740 and 1755. During the later incident, Quakers pacified the mob citing William Penn's Charter of Privileges.

properties.name: Charles Wilson Peale
properties.description: Charles Willson Peale is best remembered for his monumental portraits of George Washington and other Revolutionary War–era figures, many of which are now displayed in The Second Bank, the Greek Revival building you can see from here. Peale is also credited with organizing and opening America’s first natural history museum in Philadelphia, eventually housed just west of here on the second floor of the Pennsylvania State House. The Peale family sold the museum collection (except for the portraits) in 1849. to P.T. Barnum and Moses Kimball.

properties.name: Moses Williams
properties.description: Moses Williams was a visual artist, born to Scarborough and Lucy Peale in 1777, at which point they were enslaved by Charles Wilson Peale. Later, Moses worked as a freed man in Peale's Museum as a professional silhouettist who made black-and-white paper silhouettes for visitors of the museum. He used a physiognotrace: a portable, mechanical instrument that enabled its operators to generate multiple black-and-white profiles quickly and economically. Moses capitalized on the popularity of this method, or the 'rage for profiles,' by making over 8,000 silhouettes in just one year.

properties.name: Resistance at Christiana
properties.description: With the passage of the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850, slaveholder Edward Gorsuch and a party of eight men rode into Christiana with warrants for the arrests of four fugitives.The so-called Christiana “riot” involved a resistance effort orchestrated by fugitives and free Blacks in southern Lancaster County, Pennsylvania and resulted in the death of Gorsuch.  In defiance of the new Fugitive Slave Act, the jury of the federal treason trial, held on the second floor of Independence Hall November 1851, did not convict anyone for the killing of Edward Gorsuch, nor were any of Gorsuch’s runaways ever returned to slavery.

properties.name: Frederick Douglass
properties.description: Frederick Douglass escaped from slavery in Maryland in 1838. Six years after escaping from slavery in Maryland in 1838, at the age of twenty-six, he was invited by abolitionists to speak against slavery in Independence Square. There is no known text of his speech, but two local newspapers covered the event: the Philadelphia Public Ledger and the anti-slavery paper the Pennsylvania Freeman.

properties.name: Cherry Street Pier
properties.description: The largest unit of the project, analogous to the society at large, this module introduces the first ever public orchestra, the Public Orchestra of Philadelphia. Representing the sonic diversity of the city, the 50 musicians orchestra includes instrumentation and musical traditions from across the city; everything from Bouzouki and Oud, to DJing, to French Horn to Korean Percussion. The Public Orchestra’s public rehearsals will take place at the Cherry Street Pier, originally built as a shipping pier in 1919, now housing close to a dozen artist studios in addition to an outdoor restaurant and open performance venue.

properties.name: Elkins Park
properties.description: This is one the 22 neighborhoods that are represented by the artists of Rehearsing Philadelphia across all four modules.
